Biochemistry.message: Elevated creatinine suggests reduced kidney filtration; correlate with hydration, CKD risk, nephrotoxic drugs.
Raised urea may reflect dehydration, protein catabolism, or renal impairment.
High BUN may reflect dehydration, high protein intake, or renal impairment.
High BUN/Creatinine ratio suggests pre-renal azotemia (e.g., dehydration); review volume status.
Hyperuricemia increases gout risk; assess diet, alcohol, diuretics.
Hypernatremia—consider dehydration or endocrine causes; evaluate osmolality and fluids.
Hyponatremia—review medications, SIADH risk, and volume status.
Hyperkalemia has arrhythmia risk; check renal function and medications (ACEi/ARB/K-sparing).
Hypokalemia may cause cramps/arrhythmia; assess GI losses and diuretics.
Hyperchloremia may reflect metabolic acidosis or saline effect; correlate with bicarbonate.
Hypochloremia may occur with metabolic alkalosis or vomiting; correlate clinically.
eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73m² suggests CKD (≥3 months) if persistent; stage and manage risk factors.
HbA1c above diagnostic threshold suggests diabetes—optimize glycemic management.

Liver Function Test.message: ALT elevation suggests hepatocellular injury; review drugs, NAFLD, viral hepatitis.
AST elevation with ALT suggests hepatocellular injury; AST>ALT can suggest alcohol.
Raised ALP suggests cholestasis or bone turnover; correlate with GGT and bilirubin.
Hyperbilirubinemia—distinguish conjugated vs unconjugated; assess cholestasis/hemolysis.
Raised direct bilirubin suggests cholestasis/hepatocellular dysfunction; evaluate ALP/GGT.
Hypoalbuminemia may indicate chronic liver disease, nephrotic loss, or malnutrition.
Low total protein may reflect malnutrition, liver disease, or protein-losing states.
Transaminitis pattern—consider viral hepatitis, NAFLD/NASH, drugs; assess severity and trend.
Cholestatic pattern—evaluate bile ducts (ALP with direct bilirubin); consider obstruction or cholestasis.

Lipid Profile.message: Elevated LDL increases ASCVD risk; consider statin therapy as per guidelines.
Very high LDL—evaluate for familial hypercholesterolemia; initiate high-intensity statin.
Low HDL is a cardiovascular risk marker; optimize lifestyle (aerobic activity, weight).
Hypertriglyceridemia—address diet, alcohol, glycemic control; very high levels risk pancreatitis.
Severe hypertriglyceridemia—pancreatitis risk; urgent lifestyle and pharmacologic therapy.

Thyroid Profile.message: Elevated TSH suggests hypothyroidism; correlate with T4 and symptoms.
Low TSH suggests hyperthyroidism or suppression; correlate with T3/T4.
Subclinical hypothyroidism pattern (TSH high, T4 normal)—monitor and correlate clinically.

CBC.message: Low hemoglobin indicates anemia; pattern with MCV/MCHC helps classify (microcytic, normocytic, macrocytic).
Microcytosis suggests iron deficiency or thalassemia trait—check ferritin, RBC indices.
Macrocytosis suggests B12/folate deficiency, liver disease, hypothyroid, or medications.
Leukocytosis—consider infection, inflammation, stress; review differential.
Thrombocytopenia—assess bleeding risk, drugs, infections, immune causes.
Microcytic anemia likely—assess iron deficiency (ferritin) vs thalassemia trait.
Macrocytic anemia—consider B12/folate deficiency, alcohol, liver disease, hypothyroidism.

Immunology.message: CRP elevated—suggests active inflammation/infection; track trend and correlate clinically.
High hs-CRP indicates elevated CV risk; optimize risk factors.

Renal Function Test.message: Renal panel: creatinine raised—assess CKD, AKI, hydration, and nephrotoxic drugs.
Renal panel: eGFR <60 suggests CKD if persistent; stage and manage BP/glucose.
